doc.ContractDescription: MODIFICATION 0003 TO ADD LAURENT PICHET AS CO AND GALEN ROLADER AS COR. IGF::OT::IGF

PROJECT OVERVIEW THE GOAL OF THE RESEARCH PROJECT IS TO DECOMPOSE THE TERRESTRIAL WATER STORAGE SIGNAL INTO ITS DOMINANT SUB-SIGNALS FOR LANDSCAPES RANGING FROM<101 TO>106 KM2 AND TEMPORAL SCALES RANGING FROM HOURS TO MONTHS. FOUR RESEARCH OBJECTIVES WILL BE EVALUATED: (1) DETERMINE DOMINANT WATER STORAGE COMPONENTS IN BASINS FROM VARIED CLIMATE CONDITIONS, (2) QUANTIFY THE CORRESPONDING MAGNITUDES AND VARIABILITY OF THESE WATER STORES IN BOTH SPACE AND TIME, (3) APPLY NEW DOWNSCALING METHODS FOR CURRENT/FUTURE MEASUREMENTS NEEDED TO MODEL THE DOMINANT PROCESSES FROM OBJECTIVE NO. 1, AND (4) DETERMINE THE MINIMUM SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES FOR CLIMATE FORCING AND LANDSCAPE DATA REQUIRED TO CAPTURE THE PHYSICAL PROCESSES CONTROLLING THE DOMINANT STORAGE COMPONENTS FROM OBJECTIVE NO. 1. IN ADDITION, THREE HYPOTHESES WILL BE EVALUATED: (A) THE AMPLITUDE AND FREQUENCY OF A GIVEN WATER STORAGE SIGNAL VARIES WITH BASIN CLIMATE CONDITIONS; (B) PROPOSED DOWNSCALING TECHNIQUES FOR SOIL MOISTURE AND SNOW WATER EQUIVALENT AND PRECIPITATION PROVIDE: (B.I) A SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT IN LOCAL PARAMETER ESTIMATES, AND (B.II) A SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT IN MODEL PREDICTIONS FOR SUB-BASIN SCALES LESS THAN 103 TO 104 KM2; AND (C) THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALE OF HYDROLOGIC DATA REQUIRED TO CAPTURE KEY WATER STORAGE SIGNALS VARIES WITH BASIN CLIMATE CONDITIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS NO COST BILATERAL MODIFICATION IS TO EXTEND THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE FOR SLINS 0008AU AND 0008AX AND TO UPDATE THE CONTRACT DATA REQUIREMENTS LIST (CDRL) DATA PACKAGE (PR N0002416MR41561 AND PR N0002416MR41563).
doc.ProductorServiceCode: 1260: FIRE CONTROL DESIGNATING AND INDICATING EQUIPMENT

doc.ContractDescription: GRAVITY DATA FOR OCEAN CIRCULATION AND CLIMATE STUDIES THIS PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON THE USE OF CURRENT AND FUTURE GRAVITY DATA TO LEARN ABOUT THE OCEAN CIRCULATION AND MASS FIELDS AND THEIR RELATION TO CLIMATE. SYNTHESIS OF THE TIME-VARYING GRACE DATA WITH ALL OTHER AVAILABLE OCEAN OBSERVATIONS IN A DYNAMICALLY CONSISTENT FRAMEWORK AS PURSUED BY THE ESTIMATING THE CIRCULATION AND CLIMATE OF THE OCEAN (ECCO) PROJECT EMERGES AS A PRIMARY THEME OF THE PROPOSED WORK. PROPOSED ANALYSES INVOLVE DETAILED ASSESSMENT OF GRACE DATA UNCERTAINTIES, AND IMPROVEMENTS IN DATA PROCESSING PROCEDURES, PARTICULARLY RELATED TO THE DEALIASING OF GRACE AND FOLLOW-ON SATELLITE GRAVITY MISSIONS. OCEAN BOTTOM PRESSURE FLUCTUATIONS DERIVED FROM GRACE REPRESENT COLUMN-INTEGRATED MASS CHANGES. THESE CHANGES ARE LINKED TO KEY PROCESSES OF CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND ALL OF THE ELEMENTS CONTROLLING THE OCEAN CIRCULATION. THESE INCLUDE PRECIPITATION, RIVER RUN-OFF, ICE MASS LOSS FROM THE POLAR ICE SHEETS, COUPLING WITH THE ATMOSPHERE, THE OCEAN EDDY FIELD, TOPOGRAPHIC INTERACTIONS (TORQUES), ETC. PRIMARY SCIENCE QUESTIONS TO BE ADDRESSED CONCERN THE LINKS BETWEEN OCEAN MASS CHANGES AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY. A FOCUS WOULD BE THE IMPORTANT EFFECTS OF SELF-ATTRACTION AND LOADING PHYSICS, WHICH ARE NOT INCLUDED IN CURRENT OCEAN MODELS OR ESTIMATION FRAMEWORKS. A UNIFYING THEME IS THE DYNAMICAL IMPACT OF FRESHWATER INJECTION FROM ICE SHEET MASS LOSS, THE PHYSICAL PROCESSES THAT GOVERN THE OCEANIC RESPONSE TO SUCH PERTURBATIONS LOCALLY, REGIONALLY, AND AT GLOBAL SCALES, AND EMERGING FRESHWATER PATHWAYS IN THE OCEAN, COUPLED OBSERVATIONALLY TO HYDROGRAPHIC, GRAVITY, AND EARTH ROTATION VARIABLES.
doc.MajorAgency: GRAVITY DATA FOR OCEAN CIRCULATION AND CLIMATE STU
doc.MajorFundingAgency: GRAVITY DATA FOR OCEAN CIRCULATION AND CLIMATE STU

doc.ProductorServiceCode: R608: SUPPORT- ADMINISTRATIVE: TRANSLATION AND INTERPRETING

doc.ContractDescription: CURRENT THEORIES PROPOSE THAT PLANETS FORM IN CIRCUMSTELLAR DISKS SURROUNDING NEWLY-FORMED STARS. IN THIS PICTURE, THE INITIAL PROPERTIES OF THE DISK (MASS, RADIUS, AND METALLICITY), THE CENTRAL STAR (X-RAY LUMINOSITY), AND THE PLANETESIMALS (TIMING AND MASS DISTRIBUTION) COMBINE TO PRODUCE THE WIDE DIVERSITY OF KNOWN PLANETARY SYSTEMS. OVER THE PAST DECADE, WE HAVE DEVELOPED A MULTIANNULUS COAGULATION + N-BODY CODE TO CALCULATE THE FORMATION OF PLANETS FROM AN INPUT ENSEMBLE OF PLANETESIMALS IN AN EVOLVING GASEOUS DISK. WITH THIS CODE, WE HAVE SUCCESSFULLY MODELED THE FORMATION OF GAS GIANTS, ICE GIANTS, AND ICY DWARF PLANETS. NOW, WE PLAN TO CONSTRUCT A SUITE OF MODELS TO ISOLATE THE COMBINATION OF DISK, STAR, AND PLANETESIMAL PROPERTIES THAT LEAD TO MULTI-PLANET SYSTEMS SIMILAR TO THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM. OUR RESULTS WILL GIVE US A FIRST ESTIMATE FOR THE FREQUENCY OF PLANETARY SYSTEMS LIKE OUR OWN. COMPARISON WITH OBSERVATIONS OF OTHER PLANETARY SYSTEMS WILL ALLOW US TO IMPROVE OUR NUMERICAL MODELS OF PLANET FORMATION.
doc.MajorAgency: THE FORMATION OF THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM
doc.MajorFundingAgency: THE FORMATION OF THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM
